title: The Day My Image Disappeared
content:
Sometimes in life, things break — and sometimes that “thing” is your blog image.
Today’s post is a tribute to all the missing images out there, silently 404-ing in the digital void.
Let’s see if my blog can handle this little vanishing act without panicking.

title: Why Notes Are Your Secret Weapon
content:
Don’t trust your brain to remember every idea, bug fix, or clever solution.
Write it down. Future you will thank present you.

title: The “Almost Done” Trap
content:
Projects have a strange way of stalling at 90% completion. That last 10% feels heavier than the first 90 combined.
The fix? Break the final steps into smaller wins and celebrate each one.

title: When Bugs Teach You More Than Tutorials
content:
Fixing a bug forces you to dig deeper than you planned.
You learn systems, you learn patience, and you learn that the bug was your fault 90% of the time.

title: One Tiny Win a Day
content:
If you improve by just 1% every day, you’ll be 37 times better by the end of the year.
It’s math, but it feels like magic.

title: Coffee vs. Code
content:
Some developers run on clean, efficient code. Others run on coffee.
I run on both… and questionable amounts of late-night debugging sessions.

title: The Magic of First Drafts
content:
The first draft isn’t supposed to be perfect—it’s supposed to exist.
Once you have something on the page, you can shape it, trim it, or rebuild it.
But you can’t edit a blank screen.

title: Why Learning in Public Changes Everything
content:
Most people wait until they’re “ready” before sharing their work. The truth? You’ll never feel 100% ready—and that’s exactly why learning in public works.

When you share what you’re learning as you learn it—whether it’s coding, design, writing, or anything else—you invite feedback, build connections, and stay accountable. Your progress becomes visible, and so does your growth.

You don’t need to be an expert to help someone; beginners often explain things in ways other beginners understand best. Plus, the act of writing or speaking about what you’ve learned reinforces the knowledge in your own mind.

So start posting snippets, mistakes, wins, and lessons. Your future self will thank you—and someone else might just find your journey exactly when they need it.

title: The 5-Minute Rule for Beating Procrastination
content:
Sometimes the hardest part of any task is simply starting it. That’s where the 5-Minute Rule comes in: promise yourself you’ll work on something for just five minutes.

Five minutes is small enough to feel painless, but once you’ve started, momentum kicks in. Most of the time, you’ll find yourself continuing far beyond the initial five.

This trick works because it bypasses the brain’s resistance to “big” tasks. Instead of thinking I need to finish this huge project, you think I only need to do five minutes. That reframing is often enough to get you moving.

Next time you feel stuck, set a timer for five minutes and take the first step—you’ll be surprised how often you keep going.

title: Why Side Projects Are the Secret Weapon for Developers
content:
Side projects are more than just a fun distraction—they’re a playground for learning, experimenting, and failing safely.
When you build something outside your day job or studies, you remove the pressure to make it perfect. That freedom often sparks your most creative and innovative ideas.

Whether it’s a small script that automates a boring task or a full-fledged web app, every side project adds a new tool to your developer toolbox. And the best part? You can showcase them on your portfolio to stand out in the job market.

So the next time an idea pops into your head, don’t dismiss it. Start small, break it into steps, and watch it grow.
